The privileges and responsibilities of a life peer and a lord temporal are quite different.

A life peer is a member of the House of Lords who has been appointed by the Monarch for life, as opposed to a hereditary peer who has inherited their title. Life peers are often chosen for their expertise in a particular field, and they do not have the right to pass down their title to their children or descendants. They are entitled to certain privileges, such as the right to a seat in the House of Lords, a noble title and the ability to use the post-nominal letters "PC" (Privy Counsellor) after their name. However, they cannot sit in the House of Commons and cannot vote in general elections, as they are not elected representatives.

On the other hand, a lord temporal is a member of the House of Lords who holds a hereditary title, passed down through their family. They are entitled to similar privileges, such as a seat in the House of Lords and the use of a noble title. However, unlike a life peer, a lord temporal can vote in general elections and can sit in the House of Commons, if they choose to give up their hereditary seat.

In terms of responsibilities, both life peers and lord temporal have a duty to act in the best interests of the UK and its citizens. However, as life peers are appointed for their expertise, they may focus more heavily on specific policy areas or issues. Lord temporal may have a wider range of duties and responsibilities, as they are responsible for representing their constituency and are likely to have a broader understanding of a variety of policy areas.
